awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Zihui Zhao is "Harmonic/elliptic measure and boundary behavior of solutions to elliptic PDEs." The host institution for the fellowship is University of Chicago, and the sponsoring scientist is Carlos Kenig.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
During the fellowship, the PI studies the boundary regularity and unique continuation of elliptic PDEs and generalized minimal submanifolds.

More precisely, together with several collaborators, the PI explored the connections between the properties of a domain and of an elliptic operator, and the regularity of the corresponding solutions to Dirichlet boundary value problems, especially through the lence of harmonic and elliptic measures. The PI also studied quantitative unique continuation properties of solutions to elliptic PDEs, which is to use the local information about the growth rate of these solutions to deduce some global information. In particular, the PI, together with Kenig, explored the boundary unique continuation properties of harmonic functions with vanishing boundary data, in the setting of C^1-Dini domains. This also turned out to be the optimal setting for these properties to hold. In addition, the PI, together with De Lellis, studied the boundary regularity of multi-valued functions which minimize the Dirichlet energy with prescribed analytic boundary interface. In light of Almgren's regularity theory for area-minimizing currents, this result is expected to have geometric implication on the boundary regularity of area-minimizing currents.

Overall, the PI's work brings together tools from PDEs, harmonic analysis, geometric measure theory and geometric analysis. Partially thanks to the support of this award, the PI was able to communicate with other experts in these fields and make progress. In addition to these scientific outcomes, the support provided by this award also allowed the PI to disseminate research ideas and contribute to the education of students. This has taken place in the form of giving seminar and conference talks, teaching two series of mini-courses to introduce advanced research topics to graduate students, mentoring an undergraduate reading project, and organizing a session meeting to facilitate the exchange of research ideas, etc.


Last Modified: 08/09/2023
Modified by: Zihui Zhao
